title: Building a Visual AI Agent Network: From Prototype to Functional VueGPT
summary: The video details the development of an 'Agent Network' application, evolving from a visual prototype (V1) to a functional tool (V2) capable of integrating real AI agents. It demonstrates how to visualize, configure, and execute LLM-based tasks—specifically generating Vue.js components—by abstracting backend complexity into modular, interconnected nodes using Nuxt, Cytoscape, and Redis.

steps.action: Initialize the visual graph interface to display agent nodes and connections
steps.reasoning: Establishes the spatial environment where agents and their relationships are managed visually.

steps.action: Implement persistence to save and load agent configurations
steps.reasoning: Ensures the state of the agent network (nodes, connections, history) is retained across sessions.

steps.action: Configure a 'Real Agent' by defining its name, endpoint URL, and query parameters
steps.reasoning: Bridges the visual node to an actual backend service (LLM wrapper) capable of performing work.

steps.action: Execute a specific prompt query (Vue component generation) through the configured agent
steps.reasoning: Demonstrates the core agentic workflow: sending a natural language instruction to a specialized agent and receiving structured code.

steps.action: Extract and validate the generated code response in an external editor
steps.reasoning: Verifies the agent's output quality and utility, confirming the 'human-in-the-loop' validation step.

steps.action: Define the backend system prompt for the specific agent role
steps.reasoning: Sets the specific instructions (context) that define the agent's behavior and expertise (e.g., Vue 3 Composition API).

steps.action: Review the Nuxt application structure handling UI events and API calls
steps.reasoning: Explains the architectural glue connecting the frontend visualization to the backend agent orchestration.

key_takeaways: Visualizing agent networks helps organize and manage complex prompt libraries and functionalities.
Abstracting LLM backends into standard URL endpoints allows for modular and interchangeable agents.
Future agentic workflows will involve chaining specialized agents (composers, testers, memory) to solve larger problems.
Using a graph library like Cytoscape provides an intuitive interface for manipulating agent relationships.
